data.title: Joltin' Joe has left and gone away
data.meta_description: The United States was a nation united in homage last night after the baseball legend Joe DiMaggio, the most elegant and admired American sports star of his era, died in Florida at the age of 84.
data.text:
The United States was a nation united in homage last night after the baseball legend Joe DiMaggio, the most elegant and admired American sports star of his era, died in Florida at the age of 84.

DiMaggio died peacefully at his home in Hollywood, Florida, early yesterday, five months after undergoing lung cancer surgery. His brother Dominick, himself a major league baseball player, was at his bedside.

'DiMaggio, the consummate gentleman on and off the field, fought his illness as hard as he played the game of baseball and with the same dignity,' Morris Engelberg, his long-time friend and lawyer, said.

Flags flew at half-mast at Yankee Stadium in New York, where DiMaggio established a nonpareil reputation as a baseball player and sportsman in a 15-year career between 1936 and 1951. Outside the stadium, fans of all generations queued to pay their respects to the 'Yankee Clipper', a player who represented all that Americans love about their national game and more.

The man whose inspirational qualities were immortalised in his friend Ernest Hemingway's The Old Man And The Sea the father rallies his doubting son with the words 'Think of the great DiMaggio' was remembered yesterday as 'one of our own and one of the greatest of all time' by New York Yankees owner George Steinbrenner.

President Bill Clinton said that the United States had lost one of the century's most beloved heroes. 'This son of Italian immigrants gave every American something to believe in. He became the very symbol of American grace, power and skill,' Mr Clinton said yesterday.

Outside America, DiMaggio's fame rests largely on his 10-month marriage to Marilyn Monroe in 1954 and on the lamenting reference to him in Paul Simon's 1968 song 'Mrs Robinson'.

Where have you gone Joe DiMaggio?/A nation turns its lonely eyes to you./What's that you say, Mrs Robinson?/Joltin' Joe has left and gone away.

But those lines contain a strong clue as to why, even 30 years ago, DiMaggio had already transcended his fame on the baseball field and had come to embody a lost heroic era in American life, a status that he worked hard to retain to the day of his death.

DiMaggio's life was the quintessential story of the rise from poor Italian immigrant's son to national hero and international fame. He was the son of a San Francisco fisherman and played in the local baseball leagues before the Yankees signed him in 1934, ushering in a career which made him the most admired baseball player of the years in which America struggled out of the Depression and helped to defeat fascism.

Always wearing his trademark number 5 shirt, DiMaggio led the Yankees throughout their golden age, winning nine World Series titles in 10 seasons. Of all his many records, however, by far the most famous was his 56-game hitting streak in 1941, which remains unsurpassed to this day.

Those who watched DiMaggio in his prime, though, always emphasise the grace and athleticism which like the English cricketer Denis Compton of the same era he brought to a sport which, until then, had been dominated by tough and often crude sluggers. DiMaggio was always immaculately dressed, dignified in his behaviour and yet he invariably played to the limit.

DiMaggio retained a keen sense of his own worth and dignity. As a player he pushed for record salaries, and later guarded his privacy and reputation tenaciously, always insisting that in any public appearance at a baseball event he had to be announced last and to be described as 'the greatest living ballplayer'.

His marriage to Monroe, three years after his retirement, united America's most potent male and female icons of the early 1950s. The marriage foundered because of DiMaggio's then traditionalist male expectation that his wife would stay at home to look after him.

But DiMaggio remained devoted to Monroe after the divorce. When she died, DiMaggio took charge of the funeral and always refused ever to talk about her.

One of his final public appearances came last year, when he was honoured at the 75th anniversary dinner for Time magazine. The actor Kevin Costner said in his speech then what America was thinking yesterday: 'There are certain people's names that, when spoken aloud, are reminders of what men can be. To this day when I hear the name Joe DiMaggio it is so much more than a name.'

Life of a legend

1914: Born Martinez, California

1936: Makes debut for New York Yankees. Wins World Series

1937: Hits 46 home runs in a season

1939: Voted baseball's most valuable player. Marries Dorothy Arnold

1941: Record-breaking 56-game hitting streak

1943: Joins US army for three years. Marriage ends in divorce

1951: Retires from baseball

1954: Marries Marilyn Monroe. Divorced 10 months later

1955: Elected to Baseball Hall of Fame

1962: Chief mourner at Marilyn Monroe's funeral

1967: Coaches Oakland As for two years

1991: Honoured at White House by President George Bush

1998: Given last rites but rallies to leave hospital

1999: Dies at Florida home, aged 84
